intro: Eleusine indica var. coracana, commonly known as little millet, is an annual grass species native to Africa and widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, spike-like inflorescences that bear numerous tiny grains. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm and thrives in well-drained soils with full sun exposure. Its seeds are rich in nutrients and are used as a staple food grain in many parts of Asia and Africa. The plant also has traditional uses in herbal medicine and as a forage crop for livestock.
